page.lettertext:
fol.60r
Belgia. 1591 st
i
R
3 Fe
b
To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r
May yt please yo
r
good L. to adv
r
tise her
Ma
tie
,
that
wheras in her letter to
e
States,
& in an oth
r
to my
self, there is mention made of a former l
re
sent
hether, wh
r
in I should bee willed to propose the
self same matter to
e States, w
ch
hath bin heare
delivered by
S
r
John Norreis
, I have not yet
receaved
e foresaid letter, not any oth
r
l
re
to anie
such effect. Yo
r
L. onely in yo
r
laste of the 30 of
De
c
vouchsafed to declare that her Hig
nes
would
gladly have the use of her forces, that are out of
the 4 Townes, to
s
rve a purpose by sea to the aide
of
e
f
r
Kinge
in
Brittaine,
w
ch
was so set downe
in generall word
unto mee
w
th
out any motion unto mee
to have yet proposed to
e states of
e Country. How
the message is accepted because S
r
John Norreis will
certifie at large, I should but trouble yo
r
L. to
repeat yt again. For mine owne
ticul
r
her
Hig
nes
being pleased to take this course w
th
e country
I will give him what assistance any waie I shall
bee able. B ut oth
r
wise I am still of that opinion that
I im
ted unto yo
w
the 14 of
e laste. It is greatly
to bee douted least the new contribution, w
ch
is almoste
accorded for the levye of 3000 foote & 3000 horse will
come to nothing. For I do see by many tokens
they doe Imagine alredy, that if the forces of these
countreys shalbee much more encreased, her ma
ty
will
take yt for a fitt opportunity to lessen her charges, in
hope,
t
as then the w
th
drawing of her subject
wilbee voyd of danger to
e State. The speech is
given out,
t
the
States of Holland
have alredy
past theyr graunt for 60000 pound
st
r
for theyr portion.
They doo greatly dislike
e solicita
o
n of the frenche
for the imployment of these forces in Brittaine, And I
stand in dout th
r
upon, for that in a manner they speak
yt openly, that they will not contribute to
e Germaine
Levyes. The States doo resolve as I am told at
fol.60v
Belgia: 1501: Feb
r
this p
nt
, to write unto her Ma
ty
out of hand, & shortly
after to send some
son of purpose, to disswade her
in this matter, For I nev
r
see them for any thing
so
farre
out of temper. My warning is so short upon
the de
ture of this bearer, that I cannot write at
such length as willingly I would. The
ty of
Zeland
w
ch
was the discoverer of that matter, wherw
th
I acquainted yo
r
L. in sondry letters, is come
newly to
e Hage, & hath made his ouverture much
better by a new instruction, w
ch
I will specifye in
my next. to the end yt may be followed w
th
good
expedition &
ceeded in effectually to her Hig
nes
content.
I trust yo
r
L. will allow, that I should impart the
whole desseigne to S
r
John Norris, & use this advise for
the accomplishing of that, w
ch
is to bee required, or
oth
r
wise
fourmed of us
t
are heer. The
Gouvernor
of
Flushing,
hath had somewhat of late
disclosed unto him w
ch
himself will signify unto
yo
r
L. touching this exploit. But
e plott as yt
seemeth is yet but maymed & un
fecte.
& thus for
this p
nt
I take my humble leave. Hage. Fe
b
4. 90.
I thought it not im
tinent to send yo
w
an extract heerinclosed
of a point or two, that I have noted in c
r
taine letters that
were lately intercepted by the garrison of
Berghen.
The
speech that is heer that the
Empero
rs
Ambassado
r
are at
hand; & that theyr peace is proposed w
th
pleasing conditions
doth very much amase the discreeter sort among the people
For though the greater
te of the chiefest
sons of these
Provinces are nothing to bee douted, yet bicause the
multitude is humorous & guided by no man, & is w
th
a
ll
very weary of these daily exactions, wherew
th
their war
[res]
must be maintened, yt is greatly to be feared that
[they]
will commit some suddain follie, from w
ch
they will
not be
reclaymed by any after
suasion. In w
ch
respect
I could have
wished as I have formerly signified that S
r
John
Norreis
had come heth
r
in a fiter opportunity. For altho
ugh it be
but a borrowing of so many men for a time, yet
it will be
und
r
stood by the commons of the Country, to bee
a plaine
revocation of her Ma
t
forces.
And thus for this p
nt
[&c]
Hagh Feb
r
3. 90.
